review.title: Learning for Biomedical Information Extraction: Methodological Review of Recent Advances
review.abstract: Biomedical information extraction (BioIE) is important to many applications, including clinical decision support, integrative biology, and pharmacovigilance, and therefore it has been an active research. Unlike existing reviews covering a holistic view on BioIE, this review focuses on mainly recent advances in learning based approaches, by systematically summarizing them into different aspects of methodological development. In addition, we dive into open information extraction and deep learning, two emerging and influential techniques and envision next generation of BioIE.
histories: The version under review of Briefings in Bioinformatics(submitted on 06/16/2016)
review.COMMENTS: The version under review of Briefings in Bioinformatics(submitted on 06/16/2016)

metadata.title: Learning for Biomedical Information Extraction: Methodological Review of Recent Advances

sections.text: Biomedical Information Extraction (BioIE) is important for many applications, including clinical decision support, integrative biology and pharmacovigilance, and is therefore an active research. Unlike existing reviews that cover a holistic view of BioIE, this review focuses mainly on recent advances in learning-based approaches by systematically summarizing them in various aspects of methodological development. In addition, we focus on open information extraction and deep learning, two emerging and influential techniques, and envision the next generation of BioIE. Keywords: natural language processing; biomedical information extraction; word processing; open information extraction; deep learning.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: It has been successfully applied in clinical decision support [1,2], integrative biology [3,4] and biocuration support [5-7], and has also demonstrated great potential in pharmacovigilance [8]. Tasks include recognizing entities [9-11], identifying events [12-14], and extracting relationships [10,15,16]. Text data or companies encompass a very wide range of research efforts, resulting in huge publications as shown in Figure 1. Tasks include recognizing entities [9-11], identifying events [12-14], and extracting relationships [10-15]. Text data or corresponding authors: feifan.liu @ gmail.com Feifan Liu, PhD, is Senior Research Scientist in the Clinical Language Understanding Group, Healthcare Division at Nuance Group Understanding Communications.

sections.heading: Learning for Biomedical Information Extraction
sections.text: This year is the highest in the history of the country.

sections.heading: Challenges and Future Directions
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that this is a very complex and multi-faceted solution, capable of focusing on people's needs.

sections.heading: Funding
sections.text: This work has been supported by the National Institute of General Medical Sciences of the National Institutes of Health [grant number R01GM095476]. Content is the sole responsibility of the authors and does not necessarily reflect the official opinion of the National Institutes of Health.

Leaman [50] applied multivariate feature selection with filters and false discovery rate analysis to biomedical NER; Xia et al.
[51] evaluated an accumulated effect evaluation (AEE) algorithm for feature selection and showed improved performance in the GENIA bioNLP shared task 1 (event detection); Campos et al.
[52] described an optimization algorithm to find the feature set that better reflect the characteristics of each event type for biomedical event trigger recognition; and Fang et al.

[53] introduced an improved feature selection method by combining mutual information and class separability criteria for identifying non-redundant optimal features on multidimensional time series clinical data.

In addition, a partition-specific feature selection method was successfully applied on both protein-protein interaction[54] and drug-drug interaction [45] tasks, where candidate relation pairs are partitioned into groups based on syntactic properties and features are

[55] proposed a novel kernel named “sliding tree kernel”, which is an improved tree kernel specific to named entity recognition(NER) task.

A hash subgraph pairwise(HSP) kernel was introduced for protein-protein interaction extraction[56], which can efficiently make use of the full dependency graph that represents sentence structure and particularly capture the contiguous topological and label

[57] reported the best performing drug-drug interaction system in the DDI extraction 2011 challenge, which combined outputs from two kernelbased systems and a case-based reasoning system using majority voting.
[58] presented a weighted MKL approach for protein-protein interaction(PPI) from biomedical literature, where different

[59] further improved the state-of-the-art performance on PPI by incorporating a semantic kernel characterizing the protein-protein pair similarity using Medical Subject Heading and the context similarity using WordNet.
Similarly, the best system [60] in SemEval’13 DDI extraction applied a MKL approach linearly combining a feature-based kernel, a shallow linguistic kernel and a path-enclosed tree
combined via polynomial expansion, was showing promising result on biomedical event extraction[61].

[62] conducted an analytical study on the performance of 13 types of kernels for PPI extraction, which suggests that the system performance benefits more from novel features than from novel kernel functions.

[63] showed a novel framework for biomedical event trigger identification, where word embedding features were combined with syntactic and semantic contextual features using MKL method, achieving the state-of-the-art performance.

[66] showed that a simple linear kernel that integrates a rich set of lexical and syntactic features is able to achieve a competitive performance for DDIs, suggesting that linear kernel may perform as well as complex kernels.

[68], it has been shown that machine-assisted annotation didn’t improve annotation quality for most PHI classes and didn’t provide statistically significant time-savings compared to manual annotation of raw documents.

Crowdsourcing has been widely explored in biomedical and clinical domain [78].
medication NER in clinical trial documents[79], disease mention annotation in PUBMED literature[80], relation extraction between clinical problems and medications[81], etc.

Different techniques have been explored to improve the quality and effectiveness of crowdsourcing, including probabilistic reasoning[82] to make sensible decisions on annotation
candidates and gamified techniques[83] to motivate a continuous involvement of the expert crowd.

More recently, a method called CrowdTruth [84] was proposed for collecting medical ground truth through crowdsourcing, based on the observation that disagreement analysis on crowd annotations can compensate lack of medical expertise of the crowd.
Unsupervised biomedical NER systems described in [85] are based on phrase chunking and distributional semantics, showing competitive results on both clinical notes and biomedical literature.
[86] explored kernel-based pattern clustering and sentence parsing to tackle the PPI extraction and gene-suicide association extraction from biomedical literature.
[87] reported an unsupervised system for both entity and relation extraction from clinical records

To obtain higher quality labelling for unlabeled data, several strategies have been proposed for semi-supervised learning, such as combining active learning for PPI extraction[92], introducing event inference mechanisms to detect more event mentions from unlabeled text [93], and exploiting topic analysis to identify similar sentences for automatic labeling[94].

[183] proposed a biomedical domain-specific word embedding model by incorporating stem, chunk, and entity information, and used them for DBN-based DDI extraction and RNN-based gene mention extraction.

[184] presented a novel neural word embedding tool, Med2Vec, which can not only learn distributed representations for both medical codes and visits in electronic health record (EHR), but also allow interpreting the learned representations confirmed positively by clinical experts.

metadata.abstractText: Biomedical information extraction (BioIE) is important to many applications, including clinical decision support, integrative biology, and pharmacovigilance, and therefore it has been an active research. Unlike existing reviews covering a holistic view on BioIE, this review focuses on mainly recent advances in learning based approaches, by systematically summarizing them into different aspects of methodological development. In addition, we dive into open information extraction and deep learning, two emerging and influential techniques and envision next generation of BioIE.
metadata.creator: Microsoft® Word 2010
